author: steveharringtoned
title: Don’t wanna see no blood, don’t be a macho man
relationships: Steve Harrington & Dustin Henderson & Eddie Munson
additional_tags: Steve Harrington & Maxine "Max" Mayfield Have a Sibling Relationship
summary:
“Steve, that doesn’t make any sense,”

Aggressively dismissing their protests with repetitive hand gestures, Steve stands from the camper-vans built in seats, speaking in the way he usually did when the kids were trying to put themselves in the line of fire. “Yes, it does. Out of everyone here, I’ve suffered the least.”

He allows for a pause, just in case anyone argues. They don’t.

In which Steve is adamantly against using Max as bait for Vecna after everything; going above and beyond to make sure she never has to live through that ever again.

Even if that means taking her place.

(He doesn’t anticipate Jason Carver finding them there.)

((Or the discoveries that come when a demon is rifling through your head for the worst times of your life. Ones you may not even remember.))
notes:
CW: season 4 canon typical descriptions of violence, minor homophobia, alluded to/vague discussions of suicide (not a main character), and general mental distress . this is Vecna’s curse after all

happy reading! <3

(See the end of the work for more notes.)

(See the end of the chapter for notes.)

I hope you guys enjoyed my silly little canon divergence!

If you liked this, please check out my other works—or drop me a follow on tiktok @steveharringtoned, or twt @barmykawa <3

Part two from Eddie’s POV coming soon to you all :-)
text:
They stand there, gathered in their stolen vehicle-slash-home, acting as an audience for the vicious argument currently raging across the awkwardly placed breakfast table. Max, Nancy and Steve. Faces blazing and voices hoarse
—though Nancy more so argues in defense of her plan, the one she’d so carefully formulated all morning—unlike Steve and Max, who seem just about ready to tussle over one, minute detail of that plan.

 

“No. No way,” Steve repeats, again, for what feels like the 

billionth 

time, not even pretending to back down or compromise. 

 

“You can’t tell me what to do, Steve, it’s the only way this works!” Max slams her hands down on the table-top in a whirlwind of rage, the others still sitting back, watching in a mix of awe and fear. 

 

“Uh, 

yeah, 

I can, and I will, and uh, 

no, 

it’s not,” Hands finding his hips, Steve marks her with the stubbornness of a bull—the two of them going toe to toe is almost always a novelty when they share that common trait; inutterable amounts of will. “Nancy’s plan is brilliant. It’s great, as always,” He butters her up, trying and failing with the Harrington charm. “All I am 

saying

 is that we swap some people around.” Making a little rotating gesture with his fingers, his audience looked on expectantly.

 

“Oh yeah? And who else is Vecna going to want? You can’t just throw someone else in there and expect him to just take them, that’s shitty, Steve,” Max tosses one of her loose braids over her shoulder as she stares at the gaggle of her friends behind her, making a very obvious facial expression that’s intended to call them to her defense.

 

They stay quiet. Even Nancy has fallen silent, now, drawn into the audience of a Mayfield-Harrington showdown. 

 

Grimacing, Steve rolls his eyes. “I’m not gonna do that, 

duh.

 I’ll go instead.”

 

The passive bystanders become ultimately less passive; speaking over one another in a variety of complaints, most of them being 

no. 


 

Nancy attempts to talk him down, rapidly shaking her head.

 

“Steve, that doesn’t make 

any 

sense,” 

 

Aggressively dismissing their protests with repetitive hand gestures, Steve stands from the camper-vans built in seats, speaking in the way he usually did when the kids were trying to put themselves in the line of fire. “Yes, it does. Out of everyone here, I’ve suffered the least.”

 

He allows for a pause, just in case anyone argues. They don’t.

 

“I’ll bait that Vecna creep and when he takes it, he won’t have an easy time of it. We keep playing Kate Bush, I stall him long enough for Nancy, Robin and Erica to set him on fire in the Upside Down. Lucas and Max can blast some tunes on the sound system in the trailer, distract the bats,” Then he turns to the final two, who stare at him expectantly. “Eddie and Dustin, you’ll come with me to the Creel House. If I start floating, there’s no one I trust more than you morons to get me down safely.”

 

The silence stretches out a pause longer, before Max throws down the nearest object (a pen that then bounces away across the space,) and strides over to jab Steve in the chest with an accusatory finger. “That’s fucking stupid. You can’t do that just because you think I can’t handle it. Plus, why would he even take you?”

 

Steve sighs, eyes shifting down to her, tired but rimmed with a brotherly fondness. “Simple. I go in there, say I’ll do anything to make your pain stop—I’ll tell him we know he needs four, that Nancy told us so,” He nods in the girl’s direction before pressing on. “I’ll say you’re like a sister to me. A goddamn 

annoying

 one who likes to 

argue 

with me 

all 

the 

time

, but still. I’ll tell him that I don’t want you to die. Tell him to take me instead. Let you live.”

 

Faltering, Max fumbles for words, brow furrowed so hard Steve wonders how her face doesn't get stuck like that. “That’s 

dumb

. He’ll never believe that, he can see into our 

minds

, Steve.” 

 

Defiantly, Steve folds his arms over his chest, though there’s a hint of defensiveness about him. “That’s good. That he can read my mind.” He swallows, thickly. “Because it’s true. He’ll know it’s true, and he’ll take me instead while you stick with Lucas 

away 

from Vecna.”

 

It’s quiet, then. Max looks a mix of shocked and furious, but she doesn’t speak, only stares at him, like he’s some puzzle she can’t figure out. 

 

Steve makes use of the opportunity. “All in favour of Nancy’s plan, a little re-jigged?”

 

And Eddie, (he could just kiss him for the relief of it), speaks up for him. “Yeah, man. Sure. Henderson, Harrington and Munson? We’ll be the best bait and switch ever.”

 

Robin looks uneasy, but she trusts him, clearly, because she punches his arm. “Whatever, dingus. Me, Nance and Erica will have Henry-slash-Vecna-slash-One begging for mercy,” She loops her arm around Erica’s shoulders, giving the girl a squeeze. “Have you seen her? She’s sneaky. She’ll slip into his lair and he’ll never even know what hit him.” She grins. “And Nance is a total badass. Vecna will be sobbing for forgiveness the second she whips that felony shotgun out.”

 

“This is stupid,” Max protests, though quieter, more unsure. 

 

Lucas stands up, putting a hand on her shoulder. “No, it’s not. You’re more vulnerable, he’d take the bait quicker, sure, but… he’d kill you quicker, too. He’s already tried it once, he won’t fail again. Plus, like Steve said, he’s…”

 

“A suburbia-born rich boy with daddy’s lovely money?” Eddie pipes up. 

 

Steve holds a flinch back at that comment, not protesting for the sake of keeping the players in his field.

 

“Yeah,” Lucas nods, making a gesture to Max. “See? It’ll work. Besides, it’s not like we’re on the bench, Max, we’re literally gonna be drawing hundreds of deadly bats to Eddie’s Upside Down trailer. This just means that we have, like… a seventy percent chance of death, rather than you having a ninety-eight percent chance.”

 

Dustin shrugs, “I dunno, that sounds a little too optimistic.” Eddie's shoulder barges him. 

 

Sighing in the way she does when she is 

truly 

exhausted by the company she keeps, Nancy stands, arms folding over her army gear, and levels them all with a judgemental stare. “Fine. Now that’s figured out,” She glares at Steve, “Let’s go through it again, new additions included,” 










Hand grasping Eddie’s as the guy hesitates to push himself off the mattress, Steve yanks him upright with enough force to nearly topple them both over. Clumsily steadying the pair of them, Steve just grins lopsidedly in the direction of his current victim. Eddie smiles back, tired, yet still dimples-and-all.

 

He’s not sure if it’s because he’s about to go toe to toe with Vecna, or maybe something else—something he doesn’t have the time to consider—but as they walk through the forest in the darkness, (trying to make sure nobody spots a wanted murder,) Steve reaches out for his hand.

 

Eddie takes it, obviously, because he’s earnest and raw and compassionate in a really weird, but warm way; lacing their fingers together and squeezing. “You’re gonna be just swell, Stevie. Me and my baby have got you.”

 

For a second, Steve thinks he means 

Dustin, 

before Eddie looks over his shoulder to where his guitar has been slung. Right. 

 

“You’re sure you can play it?”

 

“I can play anything, Stevie,” Eddie brings their linked hands up, pressing a kiss to the back of Steve’s. “Even if it’s god-awful.”

 

“Hey—” Steve groans, though doesn’t drop Eddie’s hand. “Tears For Fears are 

not 

god-awful. They’re heartfelt.”

 

Scoffing, Eddie yanks him to the side a little, chuckling when Steve nearly trips. “I’m shocked you haven’t noticed yet, Stevie, but I’m not a heartfelt kinda guy.”

 

Now it’s Steve’s turn to scoff—stopping abruptly to stare into Eddie’s eyes. “You’re a bad liar, Munson. All you’ve done since I’ve met you is be heartfelt,” He looks ahead, then, at where Dustin is half-jogging, their lookout in case some weird Hawkins sucker is 

also 

creeping around in the woods at night. 

 

Eddie doesn’t say anything to that. Just looks stunned, shakes his head and drops Steve’s hand. “You gotta stop shattering my worldview, man,” Is all he offers before he skips on ahead after the younger boy, leaving Steve to stare at the back of his hand, a bit lost. 

 

He shakes it off. Steve’s got to be Vecna's bait, deciphering the Munson mystery was for another time.








Which is probably why instead of letting himself hesitate, he gently opens the door, kicking off his shoes on the step and raising his eyebrows at his company until they remember to do the same. 

 

Eddie looks blankly at him for a second, then silently 

ohhh’s, 

unzipping his boots and padding on ahead into the Creel house barefoot. Steve hears the buzz of the lamp Eddie holds fade away into the quiet of the house, flicking the switch to his own and carefully climbing the stairs as he ensures Dustin is ready to take the floor below him.

 

They search—spanning out across the vast, disconcerting space of the Creel House, their lights the only comfort available—yet also their beacons, their scythes as they search for the Reaper. 

 

Steve has no luck on the second floor, dipping in and out of bedrooms to no avail. He’s just considering abandoning the space entirely when a floorboard creaks nearby, and he turns, panicked—

 

Eddie presses a hand over Steve’s mouth, miming 

shush. 

Steve, though unable to stop his heart from racing, relaxes, glancing down at the paper note Eddie lifts, in his chicken scratch: 

Found Vecna. 


 

They silently glide down the staircase together, finding Dustin already waiting, hesitantly hovering in the entryway, his own notepad jittering in shaking hands before he eventually gathers the courage to hold it up.

 


Phase one?


 

Steve nods, gives his shoulder a comforting pat, before watching the boy be on his merry way, fleeing the house to meet Robin, Nancy and Erica in the playground on the flip side. 

 

(And really they had no way of knowing about the dog walker, because who walks their dog past creepy Creel House at this hour?) 

 

It leaves Steve and Eddie, side-by-side, waiting by the glowing light of Vecna for Dustin’s next signal. 

 

It doesn’t come immediately—so they sit together on a worn old sofa, Eddie’s knees criss-crossed, while Steve’s are at a weird angle, unable to get comfortable under the circumstances. Eddie seems to sense it, too, because he starts scribbling away on his notepad.

 


Hey.


 

Steve stares, then scribbles back.

 


Hi.


 

Eddie smiles, then, and doodles this time, quickly illustrating a stick-figure replica of himself strumming a guitar. 

 


You’re gonna be fine. 


 

The corners of his eyes crinkling, Steve leans against Eddie a little, taking his pen and drawing a replica of himself, clapping, eyes wonky hearts instead of simple dots.

 


I know, 

Steve mouths, resting his hand on top of Eddie’s. 

 

Something passes over Eddie’s face, a thought, a want—but then it’s illuminated by artificial, flickering light. Dustin’s torch.

 

Pushing off from the sofa, Steve tiptoes to the window, taking his torch out to flicker it back to Dustin. He swallows dread that tastes suspiciously like bile, and does his best to smile at Eddie, who continues to look unjustly upset by the whole ordeal. 

 

He rises from their previous place, stepping over to Steve, taking both of his hands into his and 

squeezes. 

Pulling them up to his mouth one at a time, kissing the backs of his palms (for luck, he supposes) and pressing their heads together, jittering with nerves.

 

Steve takes a deep breath, knocking their foreheads, before he releases Eddie, eyes brazenly earnest. 

 

He takes his bat from where he’s stashed it, in a sling on his back, and scoops the lamp back up again. 

 

Inhale.

 

Steve starts crashing his bat against his lamp, screaming and shouting bloody murder as he makes as much noise as he’s capable of with the wound on his throat, anything to try and get some attention. 

 

“Hey, 

asshole, 

come pick on someone your own size!” Crash, crash, crash. Steve hammers the bat into the deformed metal. “You want a real fight, instead of picking on some kids? Come and fucking get me, you overgrown piece of circumcised 

foreskin—”


 

Eddie almost laughs at that, and is met with Steve’s scorn, violently shushing him. Vecna can’t know he’s here, too—out of the two, Eddie’s far more easy pickings. 

 

“I won’t let you hurt Max ever again, jackass. Even if I die trying, I’m gonna fucking kill you,”

 

It’s that line that startles the light into dimming from Steve’s lamp—he turns to Eddie, who’s just as solemn, and follows the stairs up to the attic, chasing the thrumming of the light. 

 

It peaks in a collection of displaced furniture, damp and moth-eaten. Steve kneels, like it’s an altar, and 

prays, 

prays he takes the bait. 








He doesn’t. Not at first. Not even when Steve swears and shouts and curses his name and family ten times over. It gets so desperate that Eddie looks just about ready to speak up, to offer himself instead—and then Steve knows he can’t half-ass this.

 

“You have to take me,” He grips the hollow wood of the chair next to him. “Please. You have to. Those kids, they’re—they're 

my 

kids, y’know? I look after them, they’re like—sometimes it feels like we’re all a family.” Steve gnaws at his lip. “And that’s—it’s all I ever really wanted, when I was younger. A big ol’ family, lots of siblings, younger siblings. People who’d look at me and go 

shit, 

he’s so cool, protecting us, like that,”

 

Steve falters, taking another violent inhale of breath in through his grit teeth. “Which is why you can’t take Max, she’s—she’s a little shit, but she’s 

my 

little shit, she’s—my responsibility. So you can’t take her. Please. 

Please,” 

His chest heaves, his head bows. “You need four deaths. For four gates, Henry, Nancy—Nance told us. Let me 

help 

you.”

 

“Because Max, she’s—she’s gonna keep playing her music, and you won’t find her. But me? I’m 

offering. 

I’m—I’m giving you a free shot here. Take me.”

 

The room remains silent, save for the constant hum of the light by Steve’s head—but then, despite 

promising 

he wouldn’t, Eddie deviates from the plan. 

 

“For fuck’s sake, Steve, it’s not 

working,” 

And he looks angry, 

furious, 

as he storms over to him, shoving hard enough to land Steve unceremoniously on his ass. “What a big surprise though, right? Your hero plot, foiled. The others—they were saying how you’d grown up, but right now? This self-absorbed failure? This is all King Steve,”

 

“

Eddie,” 

Steve’s words get caught in his throat. “I’m—I’m sorry, okay? But you’re—you have to stop speaking, man, or he’ll—”






Then Eddie’s eyes dive into the back of his skull, mouth falling slack, arms splayed out at his sides, and 

God 

does Steve wish he stuck with his music lessons. Because as soon as Eddie freezes like that, there’s no time to try and even pretend to save him with some half-assed plan—he begins to levitate, despite Steve’s fighting attempts to drag him back down to the safety of the floor.  

 

He has his arms looped around his legs, trying to pull him back down—when the 

crack 

comes. Eddie’s legs, severing at odd angles, jutting out of his flesh in a garish, horrifying display, his arms swift to follow. And before Steve even has the chance to scream any louder, Eddie’s eyes explode back into his skull, and he drops. Collapses to the floor in a broken pile of limbs at all inclinations, sitting uncomfortably under his skin as Steve gathers him up in his hold. 

 

“Eddie?” He whispers, to the corpse, the empty eye sockets glaring back at him. “

Eddie?” 


 

It seems that he’d made enough of a fuss in his grief—because he hears the thunderous footfalls of someone climbing the stairs, tries his best to gather Eddie’s maimed body close to his chest, too close for Dustin to see—but it’s too little too late.

 

Dustin stands in the doorway, takes one look at the scene before him, and shrieks. Shrieks, and shrieks, and wails and howls with agony. 

 

“What did you 

do?!” 

His voice is hoarse, raw with the salt of his tears. “

You 

killed him, 

Steve, 

it was meant to be 

you!”


 

Eyes wide enough to ache, Steve stamours to try and muster some sort of apology, or excuse, or 

anything, 

but can’t—he sits there, shaking violently with the ruptured rag doll of Eddie in his arms. 

 

And then Dustin’s head snaps back, his eyes rolling into whites, and Steve really 

screams, 

then, because this is his 

worst 

nightmare, the most 

unforgivable 

failure—he falls to his knees at Dustin’s side, shaking him, sobbing—and then he begins to sing, fighting for his voice to stay vigilant, to stop 

cracking. 


 


“Turn—

turn, a—

round, 

look at what you… what you see—e,” 

 

Dustin flies upwards, hands and legs spread rigidly. Steve bowls with rage and agony, recalcitrant from his better instincts, grief tearing him apart from the inside like hands 

pushing 

his ribs open, fisting his heart and 

twisting

 it. 

 

In some cruel turn of fate, Steve is forced to watch Dustin’s limbs fracture off in unnatural directions, bear witness to the way his jaw cracks away from his face; his eyes, so gentle, so kind, nothing but gaping holes that glare at him accusingly.

 

Steve kneels, tears uncontrollably streaming down his face as his mouth hangs open, so bereaved he can’t even 

move, 

not even to try and tell the others—he can’t 

move. 

He’s stuck. And he begs, then, sobbing, for Vecna to just 

get it over with, 

to take 

him, 

please, 

please, 

please. Please. 

 

Please.

 

Eddie sits up, limbs hanging out of their sockets as he does. Dustin drags himself across the floor by his broken fingertips. 

 

“

Join us,” 

They beckon, harmonious, despite the aberrant angle of their jaws, hanging low on their faces. 

“Steve.”


 

Face raw from his own affliction, scratches from his own nails leaving angry, raised lines down his cheeks—Steve scrambles backwards, heaving, panting, panicking. 







Then it all clicks into place. 

 

“This isn’t real—” Steve laughs, laughs at the broken, contorted corpses at his feet. “You took the bait, you son of a—”

 

A vine, thick and hot, lashes out from Eddie’s misshapen mouth, curling itself around Steve’s leg and 

dragging him, 

whipping his listless body through the Creel House, pulling and pulling until his surroundings are a blur of trees, his arms and legs and neck and face a graveyard of cuts from the rubble of the forest floor, his yells and struggles heard by no one. 

 

His descent stops at the shore of Lover’s Lake. 

 

He lies there, splayed out, the pulsing sensation of the vine still curling around his appendage. Throbbing, a promise of more. 

 


“Steve,” 

And there’s Vecna—the mirror image of the description both Max and Nancy had given, all rotten flesh and unnatural anatomy. 

“Do you really think,” 

The vine jolts, taking Steve’s body into the shallows. 

“I took your 

bait? 

You,” 

Deep enough that he can’t breathe, water drawn into his nose, his mouth. “

Took,” 

And then a pause of mercy. Of nothingness. 

 


“Mine.”


 

Steve is trawled under the water, with even more force than the time before, so recent, yet so distant. As he struggles, he can make out the blinding light of three watchful pairs of eyes above him, three figures on a boat at the surface. 

 

They see him. He knows they do. But they do not come for him. 

 

Only this time when Steve is dragged through the gate, he doesn’t find himself as flesh for the bats—he’s in a car. A car, submerged in water.

 

The door opens, suddenly—the vine dragging him off of the sodden seats, and he finds himself on tarmac instead, coloured with playground chalk. 

 

It’s Hawkin’s Elementary. 

 

Steve stands, soaked to the bone, beaten and bloody, in the middle of his old preschool playground, shaken, bewildered. Because of all places, why would Vecna bring him here?

 

Nothing happened in preschool.

 


“Steve! Steven, baby!” 


 

Head snapping up to the source of the call, Steve notes a woman with a beautiful head of golden-blonde hair, flailing her arms back and forth just in case he hadn’t seen her. 

 

“Uh—hi?” Noting the absence of the vine around his leg, Steve limps forwards, baffled by the sheer, exhilarating joy on the woman’s face as he approaches. He’s not exactly a sight for sore eyes—but she looks positively delighted. 

 

She leans over the fence as he arrives, and suddenly Steve finds that the woman is much, much taller, and he is far, far smaller. 

“Oh, Buttercup. Mommy missed you,” 

And she leans over, tries to scoop him up, eyes empty and confused when he steps back away from her. 

 


“Who are you?” 

Steve finds himself saying, passive in his own younger body. 

 

The woman’s face crumples. “

Don’t say that, baby. You’re my baby, my baby boy, my son—you’re my son. 

My

 son,” 

And she grabs him, then, looping her arms around his middle and 

squeezing 

as he struggles. 

 

Now that she’s close, close enough to press kisses to the top of his head, to his face, Steve knows who she is. Only from pictures, old photo albums. 

 

It’s his aunt. His mother’s sister. Aunt Julie. 

 

She died when Steve was a kid. It was one of the many things the Harringtons never spoke about. Steve knows this. But Steve doesn’t remember this at all. Not one bit of it. 

 


“Julie!” 

He knows that voice, no matter how long it’s been since he heard it. His mother storms across the lot, flanked by police officers and men in a hospital-like uniform. 

“Put him down!”


 

His Aunt Julie doesn’t—she only holds him tighter, one arm curled around his neck too tight, too tight for Steve to breathe around, the flesh of the limb twitching and shifting back and forth from supple skin to thick, hot plant life, the vine coiling around his throat unforgivably. 

 


“He’s mine! He’s my son, you can’t take him! He’s 

mine, 

mine, mine, mine, mine!” 


 

She’s screaming, and Steve can hear some of his classmates crying, distantly, before suddenly she seizes up around him, convulsing. Collapsing to the floor, Steve is free for a moment thanks to the tasers of the ward guards, (he remembers that, a hushed argument about the expenses of his Aunt’s 

special 

hospital), before he’s grabbed by his mother, grabbed by the 

neck 

and thrown backwards.

 

He’s not in the playground anymore. His back collides with a shelf of assorted sweets, and he crumples, sitting on the linoleum floor in a small heap. 

 

It’s a supermarket, he thinks, vaguely. 

 


“Stay there. Don’t fucking move from this spot until I come to get you, Steven.” 

It’s his mother. She’s scratching at the back of her hands in the way she does when she wants to pop a pill to take the edge off—clearly, in this memory, that edge is Steve. 

“You ungrateful little shit. God, you’re just like her, sometimes? Maybe you deserve each other.” 


 

And then she’s flouncing off, and Steve’s alone in the aisle, the aisle that keeps shifting to look a little too much like Starcourt Mall for his liking. Tilting the world to the side on its axis. 

 


“Buttercup,” 

Steve’s not sure how long has passed—but it’s dark, 

dark, 

in the supermarket, the artificial lights above them flickering and dying as his Aunt Julie sprints towards him, body contorted and wrong. He doesn’t have the chance to stand before he’s breathing in something sweet. 

 

Eyes flying open, Steve’s back in the car—splayed out on the backseat, vines fastening him to the vehicle as it sinks. 

 


“It’s okay, Steven,”

 Aunt Julie soothes from the driver's seat. 

“We’ll be together forever, now. They lied to you, Stevey-bear. They told tall tales. I’m your real mother,”  


 

Steve sits there, starved for air, feeling the water rise to his knees, to the waist. 

“No,”


 


“Yes!” 

The woman punches the shotgun seat, shrieking for a moment before she breathes, calms. 

“It’s okay if you don’t understand, Buttercup. I’ll explain it all when we’re far away from here. They said I was too sick to have you, to raise you. No, no, not my baby.”


 


“It’s going to be okay, Steve,”


 

Her voice contorts, and for a flash Steve sees Vecna, glowering at him from the rear-view mirror, just before his head is submerged in the water, and he remembers, now. 

 

Remembering Aunt Julie’s funeral. Remembering the gossip, the horrified whispers. 

She’d driven the car into Lover’s Lake, and tried to take poor little Steve with her. 


 


I can't imagine how his parents must feel. You can’t control crazy. 


 

No. Steve doesn’t want to believe it. It’s not real—Vecna’s making it up to distress him. 

 

But it seems that Vecna takes that as a challenge, of sorts. Because the window closest to Steve’s submerged head suddenly shatters—he’s dragged, feet first through it, out of the car, out of the water—sprawled out on his back as he’s thrown back to the shore. 

 

He can’t feel the sand, though. And when he opens his eyes, he recognizes Joyce Byers’ ceiling, in a haze of pain and confusion. 

 

Then there’s a weight on his waist, Steve notices, in a pain-addled trance. It only takes one glance for dread to stew in his gut, brothing over until he barely remembers to suck his teeth. 

 

Because Billy is straddling him, drawing his arm back to take a swing. And another. And another, and another, and another, and another and another another another another—and Steve remembers that somewhere in the midst of Billy knocking out his teeth, breaking his nose, his jaw, his cheekbones—that Max should’ve stopped him by now. 

 

He risks a glance over Billy’s shoulder as it’s in motion to strike again—Max isn’t there. The kids aren’t either. 

 

Just Vecna. Taunting him, watching as the blood trickling down his throat is too thick to even cry out or scream anymore, studying Steve when he goes from agonized to complacent to passive. 

 

Clearly, that makes the punishment null for Vecna. Because then Billy shifts from himself to the Russian who’d tortured him, then to the 

Demogorgon, 

and that opens a new pathway of opportunity as Steve is then surrounded, the Demodogs circling him in Joyce’s home. 

 

Vecna leaves enough time for Steve to figure out what’s going to happen to him before it does. 

 

They tear into his flesh, and no matter how much he tries to remind himself that this isn’t 

real, 

he can 

feel 

it, feel their teeth, feel himself come away—

 

And he screams, because it’s all he can do. Because Vecna should’ve and could’ve killed him what feels like 

hours 

ago, but he’s toying with him, Steve decides. Torturing him.

 

Maybe it’s punishment for his arrogance. For thinking that he wouldn’t have anything Vecna could use, not like this, in this dreamscape of torment. Or maybe Vecna wants to enjoy his final kill. Because the Demodogs fade away, and his fleshy, hooked hand splays out in front of Steve’s face, and he cries. 

 

He cries, partly out of relief, partly out of acknowledgement that he’s failed. He’ll die now, when Vecna is still alive, meaning that either Steve has been here for far less time than it feels like, or something has happened to Robin, to Eddie, to Dustin, to Nancy—maybe even Erica or Max or Lucas. Somewhere, something has failed.

does

Take another hit and blame it on the good stuff.)

Stevie 

as soon as Eddie reluctantly followed them all down into the hellscape that was the Upside Down, just to save his life—or maybe, more specifically, Steve had become

In doing so, however, Eddie Munson had unfortunately learnt a few things about himself:

 
 

There was someone climbing the stairs.

Jason Carver slams his way into the attic of the Creel House, shoulders as firm as iron, face as venomous as the tail end of a super pissed off scorpion. “

Eddie

He’s not sure what to do, where to stand—so he settles for positioning himself in front of where Steve kneels, like a child trying to cover a mess they’ve made. “You and your 

buds 

haven’t exactly made—being out and about 

easy 

for me.”

done

me, 

you goddamn 

freak.

Jason, J—

this

Jason’s breath is hot on his face, and Eddie whimpers, whimpers for shame, for fear, for guilt—because if this goes any more sideways, they’re all going to die here.

The way that you ‘understand’ a five year old thinking that money 

actually

King Steve.

freak.

he’s dry-heaving and trembling hard enough to hurt.

frightened, 

because he leaves no door open to empathize with him, let alone talk him down. 

 

(Not that he could with a gun in his mouth.)

I 

don’t get is why him? Why Steve?” Yet again, he refuses to let Eddie respond, smacking the gun against the front of his teeth hard enough that he can feel his gums

freaks. 

If you were doing it because you

Munson.” 


 

Dread drips like sweat down the dampness of his neck, and as soon as Eddie understands where Jason is going with this, and the guy seems to see that, feed on it. “You must be in love with him, 

freak.” 

Eddie knows what word he really wants to use. “Maybe this is what you think 

love 

is. Sending him to be with your 

Devil 

in hell for eternity,” He raises his voice, then, taking Eddie across to where Steve kneels by the neck, drawing the gun from out of his mouth to press against the back of his head, military style. 

 

“Wake him up.”

 

Steve’s milky white eyes glare back at them. 

 

“I can’t,” Jason grabs a fist of Eddie’s hair and 

snaps 

his head back against the butt of the gun. Not the answer he wanted, clearly. “If—If I do, if I wake him up 

now, 

more people will die,”

 

Jason clicks his tongue. “

No, 

Munson, if you don’t wake him up, 

you 

die. For Chrissy, for Patrick, for Steve. I’ll blow your fucking brains out right here by his goddamn body.” 







It’s at that moment that Steve decides 

now 

he has to start levitating. 

 

And despite his fear, despite the body-numbing, mouth-bleeding 

terror, 

it’s exactly what Eddie needs.

 

While Jason’s head snaps to marvel at Steve’s body beginning to lift, Eddie swerves out of his line of fire before turning and 

tackling 

him to the floor. He takes his wrists and straddles him, going for the gun—it’s the only thing Eddie really succeeds at, tossing it across the room.

 

In doing so, he leaves himself open for Jason to roll them over, smacking Eddie’s head against the floor once, twice—he loses count after the fourth or fifth, and Jason loses interest, deciding that fists are much more exciting instead. Eddie can see Steve, though blurred and tinged with the red of his own blood running into his eyes—lifting higher, higher, limbs falling stiff out behind him. 

 

Not that it matters—Eddie was never a fighter. Eddie never started fights, they sought him out and beat him down, it was never fair, or even, just someone deciding they didn’t like him, the 

freak, 

deciding that his mere existence had earned him the taste of his own blood, earned him a crooked nose that was now entirely facing the wrong way. 

 

Jason had definitely decided this was the case—he sits on Eddie’s chest and tears out handfuls of hair, swings and swings and swings until Eddie can’t see, can’t hear anything but his panting cries that this was all for 

Chrissy, 

but if Eddie knew anything about Chrissy, kind, gentle Chrissy—she wouldn’t have wanted this whether Eddie murdered her or not. 

 

When he’s certain that Eddie’s in no state to follow after him, Jason stands, and barrages him with kicks in his side, gives his fists a rest—he doesn’t stop, not until he can hear the crack of Eddie’s ribs, until his cries of pains subside into muted whimpers. 

 

Eddie can’t move. He’s a little sure that he might be missing one or two teeth, too. There’s blood coming from his nose in gushing waves, a wound on his head that’s blinding him as it streams down his face. 

 

His fingers aren’t broken, at least. Jason didn’t get there yet. 

 

It’s dwelling upon Jason when Eddie comes to the horrifying comprehension that Jason is gone. And Eddie can’t follow after him.

 

The cool metal of the gun against the back of his head confirms his worst suspicions. 

 

“Jason. 

Jason,” 

Eddie spits out one of his teeth, dry heaving over the floorboards of the attic. He knows it’s useless, begging for his life—Jason decided that he wanted Eddie dead as soon as Chrissy’s body was found in his trailer. But he can’t help it, nor can he help sobbing, sobbing bitterly because he can’t believe this is how it all ends, how Nancy’s plan is totally ruined, because Eddie’s brains are about to decorate the floor in the Creel House and nobody will save Steve, and Hawkins will fall. 

 

Jason gives him no comfort into the hands of death. Instead, he kneels, picks Eddie up by the hair and laughs, cruelly, into his ear, and clicks the safety off. “See you in hell, 

freak,”


 

And there’s a crack, an ugly, gruesome crack. It doesn’t sound much like a gunshot, but Eddie supposes it might sound different when it’s lodged in his brain. 

 

A handful of seconds pass.

 

Eddie’s not dead. Jason Carver collapses in a heap next to him. 

 

“Eddie!” With the last of his strength, he rolls over onto his back, coughing up a mouthful of blood. 

 

He could cry for joy. It’s 

Dustin. 

Worse for wear, but 

Dustin. 

Grinning, bruised and definitely beaten (by one of Jason’s friends, no doubt, he thinks, sick to his stomach) holding Steve’s nail bat like the Olympic torch. 

 

His other hand is stuck out, an offering. Urgent—as he notices Steve, poor Steve, convulsing in the air, the time he has left slim, yet crucial—for all of them. 

 

Steve’s arm breaks. 

 

They’re out of time.

 

Taking it, Eddie stands, choking back the urge to throw up his insides—and takes his guitar, standing at the foot of Steve’s hovering body, and uses whatever last life he has left kicking in him to play that stupid, corny song he likes. 

 

He sings, though his voice is raw and pain litters his every word. He strums his guitar though his fingers shake and he thinks his shoulder might not be in its socket. 

 

Eddie plays for every person Vecna killed, for every injury inflicted on the kids since this all begun, for Nancy Wheeler and her felony shotgun, for Robin Buckley and her clumsy charm, for Max Mayfield and her admirable stubborn fire, for Lucas Sinclair for his deep compassion, for Erica Sinclair and her wits, her bravery despite her age. Eddie plays for Dustin, who can barely stand, but does so, stands 

with 

him, keeping him upright, his light in the darkness, his best friend. 

 

Eddie plays for Steve, 

swears 

he can hear his voice, his anguish—and Eddie plays harder, plays until tears are running rampant down his face, til he can barely breathe for pain and love and relief and fear. 

 

Plays for Steve and his stupid, lopsided smile, plays for Steve and his perfectly mussed hair, plays for Steve and his earnest affection, Steve and his moronic bravery, Steve and his utter dedication to protecting them all. 

 

And Eddie knows that if this isn’t enough—if they lose, now, that they would’ve fought as hard as they could. Steve, Eddie and Dustin, together, on the dusk of their final day, bleeding together, dying together. 

 

Eddie thinks that if he should die, there are no better people for him to die with. 

 

He pushes that sentiment into the rasp of his voice, contorts his body to force it to keep 

playing, 

refuses to fall, now, though he can feel death clambering at him, clawing. 

 

Eddie plays for Steve. Plays with more heart than he’s ever had. 







Steve drops. 


Eddie follows suit. 










The hospital only had pink left for Steve’s cast. Eddie thinks it’s cute, Dustin thinks it’s funny. 
The three of them are in the same wing of Hawkin’s medical for a couple days, with Eddie and Dustin’s ribs both a sorry state, though Eddie much worse for wear. He supposes that Dustin must take after Steve that way—he managed to fend of Jason’s sadistic friend far better than Eddie did Jason, and it’s evident. Evident in the way that boot prints climb up his side and his back, evident in the way that the nurse saw the break of Eddie’s nose and said if Jason had hit any harder it might’ve killed him for good. Evident in the severe shoulder injury they say he might never fully recover from, evident in the minor fracture of his jaw and the severe concussion that knocked him out in the attic, leaving Dustin with his two favorite, older male friends completely unconscious at his side. 
Hawkins Lab were quick with Eddie’s government pardon—they brought it into the hospital with the three of them, in fact, confirmation of another killer, some made up serial murderer from Europe, as opposed to an alternate dimension. 
Eddie’s grateful for that. He doesn’t really fancy being cuffed to a hospital bed, it’d be a bit on the nose and it’s not how he likes it to go, typically. 
(Steve had laughed at that, the first time he made the joke. Dustin had just scrunched up his face and looked confused.)
Physically, Steve got off the best of the three of them. Mentally, not so much. The entire stay at the hospital he refused sleep, the doctors hooking him on the real good stuff without mentioning it until he couldn’t keep his eyes open any longer. 
It didn’t work, though. Vecna’s curse clearly triumphs over all human drugs, because Steve had a couple hours of shut eye until he woke up in complete, screaming, sobbing hysterics. 
Eddie had clambered into his bed, after that. Had curled up like a wounded dog at his side and listened, casting a hand through his hair as Steve whispered every last horror he’d been shown from start to finish, Eddie unsure whether to be flattered or sickened by his repeated guest appearances. 
Eddie listens, and realizes that he’d take another life-threatening beating from Jason before having to go through something like that, the way Steve viscerally describes it, sometimes having to pause just to stop himself from heaving again. 
(It doesn’t help dissuade Eddie from thinking, just maybe, that Steve might be the most fucking badass guy in the universe.)
Max is one of the first kids to visit, or maybe they gave her a chance to come and see Steve alone. Either way, Eddie wakes up in the early morning and she’s there, a nasty wound on her neck almost identical to Steve’s, whispering away in hushed voices as Dustin snores lowly and Eddie tries to keep his breath even. 
Steve talks through what he saw with her. He sounds a little less aggrieved, but he also can’t bring himself to go into as much detail as he did with Eddie. 
Eddie feels bad when he’s pleased by that. Mostly because he knows that Steve is trying to spare her, she’s already had her time with Vecna, she doesn’t need the additional nightmare fuel of Steve’s more… elongated experience. 
Nancy, Robin, Lucas and Erica come together as a unit. They explain their end of things—the vines that had almost killed the girls, Lucas speaking of the bat that had almost killed Max, showing off his own gnarly scar he got from saving her. Robin speaks in colour and depth about how amazing Nancy’s kill shots were, then gushes about Erica and her total vicious destruction of Vecna’s physical form. 
Steve catches Eddie’s eye across the room, and finds himself met with the same fondness for their guests. 
The girl with superpowers comes to make sure that Steve is alive. Their conversation is a bit stilted, no doubt because from what Steve had said, this girl had seen a little too far into his brain—but he gives her a hug nonetheless, thanks her for saving the day. For saving him. 
Eddie could feel jealous about that, but he doesn’t—because Steve had climbed into his bed, in the middle of the night, wordlessly lying beside him for a while. Then he can’t stop talking, mumbling thank you’s and sorry’s, Eddie finally discerning the strange tinge of Steve’s expressions as guilt. Guilt every time he sees his sling, the bandages around his head, the bandages around his middle. 
Eddie calls him stupid. They kiss.
 
(Not quite in that order.)
 
Dustin goes home, first. Mrs Henderson comes in and fusses over the lot of them, cries, and kisses all three of them on the head until Dustin is so mortified he flees the building entirely. 
Eddie is discharged alongside Steve by lunchtime.
Steve can’t drive, so they walk—it’s a long trek, but Eddie feels like they need the air and the space, the time to just be side by side without the threat of death. They’re quiet, and it’s nice, comfortable—their hands are linked and Eddie is thinking about the stupid guilt on Steve’s stupid face and that’s when he calls him stupid, out of the blue. 
Steve takes it well—he’s heard it before, mostly because it’s true. He is stupid. Eddie finds it charming. 
They argue playfully, taunting each other until they’re both so worked up they decide that no guilt is allowed for either of them, and Steve lasts not even five seconds before he tries to refute that again—
So, naturally, Eddie pins him up against a tree and kisses him. Kisses him in the middle of the forest, bathed in midday light yet also the cool shelter of the thick wildlife above them.
Steve takes a minute to reciprocate, but Eddie doesn’t take it personally—Steve is sometimes a bit slow on the uptake, even when the uptake is another boy trying to make out with him against a tree. Nonetheless, they get there, and they kiss until Eddie is groaning in pain from his broken and bruised ribs, and Steve is about ninety percent sure that if they continue he’s going to pop some stitches the hospital did their best sewing in over the demobat flesh wounds. 
When they reach Eddie’s trailer, Steve waits outside. 
Eddie reunites with his Uncle Wayne—who’s clearly been told to expect him, a suitcase by the door as he sits, stone-faced on the sofa, warmth flooding the lines of age and easing them into pure, unadulterated relief when his nephew finally returns. 
Insults fly readily at him, bouncing off of him like the waxy layer on a leaf against rainwater. Eddie is just grinning, crying, and then hugging his old man, who promises he never doubted him, not even for a second—and Eddie believes him, because Nancy Wheeler had told him all about his Uncle Wayne adamantly defending him like his own. 
 
“You are my own,” He’d said, before making a remark about how Steve was probably going to keel over if Eddie left him outside for much longer.
(Eddie invites Steve inside.)
 
They sleep together in the trailer, in Eddie’a bed, a tangle of sore limbs and injured sides, concussed and high on the good stuff Hawkins sent them home with. It’s tender, just a night of lying there in silence with each other, basking in the aftermath of their trauma, their fear. 
Eddie tells Steve he don’t think he’ll ever be okay. Steve says he doesn’t think he will be either. 
Maybe they’ll heal together. Maybe they’ll crash and burn, self destruct. 
Eddie doesn’t think he minds—so long as they do it together.
